questions.question:
Question 1: During her antenatal ward rounds, an intern noticed a USG report indicating the presence of 
just one kidney in the fetus. Which of the following association would be expected to be seen 
in the baby?
questions.explanation:
530 
Sold by @itachibot The presence of a single umbilical artery can be expected to be seen in the case of a baby with 
unilateral renal agenesis. Renal agenesis occurs secondary to a defect of the Wolffian duct, ureteric bud, or metanephric 
blastema. It is often discovered during the course of an evaluation for other congenital anomalies 
(VACTERL syndrome). Its incidence is increased in newborns with a single umbilical artery. The 
contralateral kidney undergoes compensatory hypertrophy. Some children also have contralateral 
vesicoureteral re■ux. Most males have an ipsilateral absent vas deferens. NOTE: VACTERL syndrome - Vertebral defects, imperforate Anus, Congenital heart disease, 
Tracheo-Esophageal fistula, Renal and Limb defects

questions.question:
Question 2: A 10-month-old female is brought to the clinic with a 102° F fever for 2 days. The mother says 
that she also cries during urination. The history is significant for similar episodes in the past 
which were treated with antibiotics. Urine analysis shows nitrite-positivity and gram-negative 
bacteria are seen on urine microscopy. Which of the following anomaly is most commonly 
associated with this child's condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent urinary tract infection. The most common 
anomaly associated with this condition in children is vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). VUR usually is congenital and often familial. It is more common in females. It occurs when the 
submucosal tunnel between the mucosa and detrusor muscle is short or absent. The image below shows VUR grading

questions.question:
Question 3: A pediatrician suspects vesicoureteric reflux in a girl with a history of recurrent urinary tract 
infections. What is the investigation of choice to confirm this condition?
questions.explanation:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteral reflux. Recurrent febrile urinary tract infections in a child should raise the suspicion of an anatomical 
defect like vesicoureteric reflux as the cause. Compared to other investigations, a VCUG provides 
more anatomic information. It can demonstrate: 531 
Sold by @itachibot • Vesicoureteral reflux • Duplex collecting system • Ectopic ureter • Paraureteral (bladder) diverticulum • Bladder outlet obstruction • Signs of voiding dysfunction, such as a spinning top urethra

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following is the first-line imaging investigation done in a child presenting with 
an episode of UTI?
questions.explanation:
In a child presenting with an episode of urinary tract infection (UTI), initial imaging should be 
ultrasonography of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder. A voiding cystourethrogram is indicated only if the ultrasound study is abnormal, the patient has 
atypical features or after a recurrent febrile UTI. DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan may be done after 4–6 months of acute infection as it may 
help to locate and delineate the scarring

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is the most common cause of urinary tract infection in children?
questions.explanation: Urinary tract infections in children are most commonly caused by the following: • Escherichia coli (Most common) • Klebsiella species • Proteus species • Staphylococcus saprophyticus • Enterococcus • Adenovirus and other viral infections (cause cystitis and gross hematuria)

questions.question:
Question 6: A mother is concerned that her 1-year-old daughter has been having repeated episodes of UTI 
since birth. The pediatrician ordered a voiding cystourethrogram, which revealed reflux of 
urine into the upper collecting systems without any dilation. Under which grade of 
vesicoureteral reflux will this presentation be classified?
questions.explanation:
Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) severity is graded according to the appearance of the urinary tract on 
a contrast voiding cystourethrogram. It is classified into 5 grades (Grade I to V): Grading of vesicoureteral re■ux: • Grade I- VUR into a non-dilated ureter • Grade II- VUR into the upper collecting system without dilation • Grade III- VUR into the dilated ureter and/or blunting of calyceal fornices. 532 
Sold by @itachibot • Grade IV- VUR into a grossly dilated ureter • Grade V- Massive VUR, with significant ureteral dilation and tortuosity and loss of the papillary 
impression.

questions.question:
Question 7: Ashi, a 12-year-old girl presented with features of hematuria, headache, and blurring of 
vision. Her past history is significant for recurrent UTI. On examination, she was found to 
have a BP of 150/110 mmHg. Investigations revealed mild renal scarring and urine analysis 
showed broad casts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.c: Posterior urethral valve with chronic renal failure
options.d: Reflux uropathy with chronic renal failure

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of reflux uropathy with chronic renal failure. The pathogenesis of vesicoureteral reflux is as follows: Loss of renal parenchyma and renal scarring reduces renal function significantly. This renal 
insufficiency leads to renin-mediated hypertension and further progresses to end-stage renal 
disease. Re■ux nephropathy remains a common cause of hypertension in children. 533 
Sold by @itachibot Broad casts or renal failure casts are associated with end-stage renal disease.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is the most common cause of abdominal mass in neonates?
questions.explanation:
Multicystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK) is the most common cause of an abdominal mass in the 
newborn but is mostly non-palpable at birth. In most cases, it is discovered incidentally during prenatal sonography. In some patients, the cysts 
are identified prenatally, but the cysts regress in utero, and no kidney is identified on imaging at 
birth. MCDK is usually unilateral and generally not inherited, unlike polycystic kidney disease 
(PKD). Contralateral hydronephrosis is present in 5-10% of patients.

questions.question:
Question 9: Komal, a high school student developed a fever after she came back from a trip with her 
friends. She also complained about pain while urinating. She says she has been having these 
episodes frequently for the past few years. Her father and her grandfather are a known case of 
cystic kidney disease. Her urine analysis is indicative of UTI with hematuria. Renal 
ultrasound was done and its findings are shown below. Which of the following chromosomes 
are associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
The presence of multiple cysts seen on the ultrasound(image) along with a positive family history 
point towards the diagnosis of autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease. Chromosomes 16 
and 4 are associated with this condition. Autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease inheritance: Chr16 short arm

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following conditions is not associated with the lesion seen in the image?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a horseshoe kidney. It is not associated with the posterior urethral valve. Horseshoe kidney is the most common congenital anomaly of the kidneys. Horseshoe kidney is caused due to the fusion of the lower poles of the kidney. The lower border of 
the kidneys usually lie in front of L3 vertebra due to arrest of ascent. The common associations of horseshoe kidney are: • Vesicoureteral reflux • Wilms tumor • Multicystic dysplastic kidney • Turner’s syndrome 534 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A young girl presents with the complaints of continuous dribbling of urine. However, she also 
voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. What 
is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical presentation of a young girl with continuous dribbling of urine, despite normal 
voiding, strongly suggests the diagnosis of an ectopic ureter. An ectopic ureter refers to a condition where the ureter drains outside the bladder. It is more 
common in females and opens either into the urethra below the sphincter or into the vagina. 
Hence, they present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly 
(paradoxical incontinence). The terminal part of the ureter is frequently narrowed, leading to hydroureteronephrosis. Urinary 
tract infections (UTIs) are common due to urinary stasis. In males, ectopic ureters usually enter the posterior urethra above the external sphincter, hence 
they are usually continent and most patients present with UTI or epididymitis. Investigations include renal ultrasound (USG), voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), and renal scan 
to assess function. USG shows a hydronephrotic kidney or dilated upper pole and ureter. If there 
is a satisfactory function, the recommended treatment options are ureteral reimplantation into 
the bladder or ureteroureterostomy. The poor function may require partial or total nephrectomy. Other options: Option B: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, typically obstructive due to a 
small ureteral opening. In childhood, they commonly present with infections. Larger ureteroceles 
can cause obstruction at the bladder neck. Option C: Congenital megaureter (dilated ureter) presents UTI, urinary stones, hematuria, and 
flank pain because of urinary stasis. Option D: Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is characterized by the retrograde flow of urine from the 
bladder to the ureter and kidney. They usually present with recurrent attacks of UTI.

questions.question:
Question 12: 528 
Sold by @itachibot A 3 yr old male child with left flank pain is diagnosed to have an acute UTI. On USG, the left 
ureter was found to be duplicated. The most probable site of the opening of ectopic ureter will 
be?
questions.explanation: Opening of the ectopic ureter in male (most to least common) : • Posterior urethra (prostatic) above the external sphincter • Seminal vesicle • Prostatic utricle • Ejaculatory duct • Vas deferens

questions.question:
Question 13: A newborn is being evaluated for anuria. Imaging reveals renal agenesis and pulmonary 
hypoplasia. The delivery was complicated due to oligohydramnios. Which of the following is 
the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
535 
Sold by @itachibot A newborn infant with anuria, renal agenesis, and pulmonary hypoplasia, with a history of 
oligohydramnios, is suggestive of Potter's sequence Potter's sequence is characterized by the triad of: • Renal agenesis • Oligohydramnios • Pulmonary hypoplasia Option B: Pierre–Robin syndrome: micrognathia, retrognathia, glossoptosis. Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia: It can present with pulmonary hypoplasia but other 
features like renal agenesis, anuria will not be seen. Option D: CHARGE syndrome: Coloboma of the eye, Heart anomaly, choanal Atresia, 
Retardation, Genital and Ear anomalies.

questions.question:
Question 14: Antenatal hydronephrosis due to PUJ obstruction is defined as the anteroposterior diameter 
of the renal pelvis of more than  
 in the third trimester.
questions.explanation:
Anteroposterior diameter of the renal pelvis of >7 to 7.5 mm in the third trimester denotes 
antenatal hydronephrosis due to pelvic ureteric junction (PUJ) obstruction. Definition of antenatal hydronephrosis by anteroposterior diameter: Degree of antenatal hydrone

questions.question: Question 16: Ask-Upmark kidney refers to
questions.explanation:
The Ask-Upmark kidney is also termed segmental hypoplasia. Renal segmental hypoplasia: • Severe segmental renal atrophy with loss of parenchymal elements in small kidneys is commonly 
known as segmental hypoplasia. • It refers to small kidneys, usually weighing not more than 35 g. • The scars are seen as cortical depressions overlying shrunken medullary pyramids and their 
dilated calyces, and they are characterized histologically by colloid-filled tubular microcysts and a 
paucity or absence of glomeruli. • Most patients are 10 years or older at diagnosis and have severe hypertension. • Nephrectomy usually controls the hypertension. 537 
Sold by @itachibot Disorders of the Nervous System
